column2: [Sidenote: Theory that stations actually correspond to faculty.]
column3: [Sidenote: Theory that stations actually correspond to faculty.]

column2: An aristocratic society might accordingly be a perfect heaven if the variety and superposition of functions in it expressed a corresponding diversity in its members' faculties and ideals.
column3: An aristocratic society might accordingly be a perfect heaven if the variety and superposition of functions in it expressed a corresponding diversity in its members' faculties and ideals.

column2: And, indeed, what aristocratic philosophers have always maintained is that men really differ so much in capacity that one is happier for being a slave, another for being a shopkeeper, and a third for being a king.
column3: And, indeed, what aristocratic philosophers have always maintained is that men really differ so much in capacity that one is happier for being a slave, another for being a shopkeeper, and a third for being a king.

column2: All professions, they say, even the lowest, are or may be vocations.
column3: All professions, they say, even the lowest, are or may be vocations.

column2: Some men, Aristotle tells us, are slaves by nature; only physical functions are spontaneous in them.
column3: Some men, Aristotle tells us, are slaves by nature; only physical functions are spontaneous in them.

column2: So long as they are humanely treated, it is, we may infer, a benefit for them to be commanded; and the contribution their labour makes toward rational life in their betters is the highest dignity they can attain, and should be prized by them as a sufficient privilege.
column3: So long as they are humanely treated, it is, we may infer, a benefit for them to be commanded; and the contribution their labour makes toward rational life in their betters is the highest dignity they can attain, and should be prized by them as a sufficient privilege.

column2: Such assertions, coming from lordly lips, have a suspicious optimism about them; yet the faithful slave, such as the nurse we find in the tragedies, may sometimes have corresponded to that description.
column3: Such assertions, coming from lordly lips, have a suspicious optimism about them; yet the faithful slave, such as the nurse we find in the tragedies, may sometimes have corresponded to that description.

column2: In other regions it is surely true that to advance in conventional station would often entail a loss in true dignity and happiness.
column3: In other regions it is surely true that to advance in conventional station would often entail a loss in true dignity and happiness.

column2: It would seldom benefit a musician to be appointed admiral or a housemaid to become a prima donna.
column3: It would seldom benefit a musician to be appointed admiral or a housemaid to become a prima donna.

column2: Scientific breeding might conceivably develop much more sharply the various temperaments and faculties needed in the state; and then each caste or order of citizens would not be more commonly dissatisfied with its lot than men or women now are with their sex.
column3: Scientific breeding might conceivably develop much more sharply the various temperaments and faculties needed in the state; and then each caste or order of citizens would not be more commonly dissatisfied with its lot than men or women now are with their sex.

column2: One tribe would run errands as persistently as the ants; another would sing like the lark; a third would show a devil's innate fondness for stoking a fiery furnace.
column3: One tribe would run errands as persistently as the ants; another would sing like the lark; a third would show a devil's innate fondness for stoking a fiery furnace.

column2: [Sidenote: Its falsity.]
column3: [Sidenote: Its falsity.]

column2: Aristocracy logically involves castes.
column3: Aristocracy logically involves castes.

column2: But such castes as exist in India, and the social classes we find in the western world, are not now based on any profound difference in race, capacity, or inclination.
column3: But such castes as exist in India, and the social classes we find in the western world, are not now based on any profound difference in race, capacity, or inclination.

column2: They are based probably on the chances of some early war, reinforced by custom and perpetuated by inheritance.
column3: They are based probably on the chances of some early war, reinforced by custom and perpetuated by inheritance.

column2: A certain circulation, corresponding in part to proved ability or disability, takes place in the body politic, and, since the French Revolution, has taken place increasingly.
column3: A certain circulation, corresponding in part to proved ability or disability, takes place in the body politic, and, since the French Revolution, has taken place increasingly.

column2: Some, by energy and perseverance, rise from the bottom; some, by ill fortune or vice, fall from the top.
column3: Some, by energy and perseverance, rise from the bottom; some, by ill fortune or vice, fall from the top.

column2: But these readjustments are insignificant in comparison with the social inertia that perpetuates all the classes, and even such shifts as occur at once re-establish artificial conditions for the next generation.
column3: But these readjustments are insignificant in comparison with the social inertia that perpetuates all the classes, and even such shifts as occur at once re-establish artificial conditions for the next generation.

column2: As a rule, men's station determines their occupation without their gifts determining their station.
column3: As a rule, men's station determines their occupation without their gifts determining their station.

column2: Thus stifled ability in the lower orders, and apathy or pampered incapacity in the higher, unite to deprive society of its natural leaders.
column3: Thus stifled ability in the lower orders, and apathy or pampered incapacity in the higher, unite to deprive society of its natural leaders.

column2: [Sidenote: Feeble individuality the rule.]
column3: [Sidenote: Feeble individuality the rule.]

column2: It would be easy, however, to exaggerate the havoc wrought by such artificial conditions.
column3: It would be easy, however, to exaggerate the havoc wrought by such artificial conditions.

column2: The monotony we observe in mankind must not be charged to the oppressive influence of circumstances crushing the individual soul.
column3: The monotony we observe in mankind must not be charged to the oppressive influence of circumstances crushing the individual soul.

column2: It is not society's fault that most men seem to miss their vocation.
column3: It is not society's fault that most men seem to miss their vocation.

column2: Most men have no vocation; and society, in imposing on them some chance language, some chance religion, and some chance career, first plants an ideal in their bosoms and insinuates into them a sort of racial or professional soul.
column3: Most men have no vocation; and society, in imposing on them some chance language, some chance religion, and some chance career, first plants an ideal in their bosoms and insinuates into them a sort of racial or professional soul.

column2: Their only character is composed of the habits they have been led to acquire.
column3: Their only character is composed of the habits they have been led to acquire.

column2: Some little propensities betrayed in childhood may very probably survive; one man may prove by his dying words that he was congenitally witty, another tender, another brave. But these native qualities will simply have added an ineffectual tint to some typical existence or other; and the vast majority will remain, as Schopenhauer said, _Fabrikwaaren der Natur_.
column3: Some little propensities betrayed in childhood may very probably survive; one man may prove by his dying words that he was congenitally witty, another tender, another brave. But these native qualities will simply have added an ineffectual tint to some typical existence or other; and the vast majority will remain, as Schopenhauer said, underscore Fabrikwaaren der Natur underscore.

column2: Variety in human dreams, like personality among savages, may indeed be inwardly very great, but it is not efficacious.
column3: Variety in human dreams, like personality among savages, may indeed be inwardly very great, but it is not efficacious.

column2: To be socially important and expressible in some common medium, initial differences in temper must be organised into custom and become cumulative by being imitated and enforced.
column3: To be socially important and expressible in some common medium, initial differences in temper must be organised into custom and become cumulative by being imitated and enforced.

column2: The only artists who can show great originality are those trained in distinct and established schools; for originality and genius must be largely fed and raised on the shoulders of some old tradition.
column3: The only artists who can show great originality are those trained in distinct and established schools; for originality and genius must be largely fed and raised on the shoulders of some old tradition.

column2: A rich organisation and heritage, while they predetermine the core of all possible variations, increase their number, since every advance opens up new vistas; and growth, in extending the periphery of the substance organised, multiplies the number of points at which new growths may begin.
column3: A rich organisation and heritage, while they predetermine the core of all possible variations, increase their number, since every advance opens up new vistas; and growth, in extending the periphery of the substance organised, multiplies the number of points at which new growths may begin.

column2: Thus it is only in recent times that discoveries in science have been frequent, because natural science until lately possessed no settled method and no considerable fund of acquired truths.
column3: Thus it is only in recent times that discoveries in science have been frequent, because natural science until lately possessed no settled method and no considerable fund of acquired truths.

column2: So, too, in political society, statesmanship is made possible by traditional policies, generalship by military institutions, great financiers by established commerce.
column3: So, too, in political society, statesmanship is made possible by traditional policies, generalship by military institutions, great financiers by established commerce.

column2: If we ventured to generalise these observations we might say that such an unequal distribution of capacity as might justify aristocracy should be looked for only in civilised states.
column3: If we ventured to generalise these observations we might say that such an unequal distribution of capacity as might justify aristocracy should be looked for only in civilised states.

column2: Savages are born free and equal, but wherever a complex and highly specialised environment limits the loose freedom of those born into it, it also stimulates their capacity. Under forced culture remarkable growths will appear, bringing to light possibilities in men which might, perhaps, not even have been possibilities had they been left to themselves; for mulberry leaves do not of themselves develop into brocade.
column3: Savages are born free and equal, but wherever a complex and highly specialised environment limits the loose freedom of those born into it, it also stimulates their capacity. Under forced culture remarkable growths will appear, bringing to light possibilities in men which might, perhaps, not even have been possibilities had they been left to themselves; for mulberry leaves do not of themselves develop into brocade.

column2: A certain personal idiosyncrasy must be assumed at bottom, else cotton damask would be as good as silk and all men having like opportunities would be equally great.
column3: A certain personal idiosyncrasy must be assumed at bottom, else cotton damask would be as good as silk and all men having like opportunities would be equally great.

column2: This idiosyncrasy is brought out by social pressure, while in a state of nature it might have betrayed itself only in trivial and futile ways, as it does among barbarians.
column3: This idiosyncrasy is brought out by social pressure, while in a state of nature it might have betrayed itself only in trivial and futile ways, as it does among barbarians.

column2: [Sidenote: Sophistical envy.]
column3: [Sidenote: Sophistical envy.]

column2: Distinction is thus in one sense artificial, since it cannot become important or practical unless a certain environment gives play to individual talent and preserves its originality; but distinction nevertheless is perfectly real, and not merely imputed.
column3: Distinction is thus in one sense artificial, since it cannot become important or practical unless a certain environment gives play to individual talent and preserves its originality; but distinction nevertheless is perfectly real, and not merely imputed.

column2: In vain does the man in the street declare that he, too, could have been a king if he had been born in the purple; for that potentiality does not belong to him as he is, but only as he might have been, if _per impossibile_ he had not been himself.
column3: In vain does the man in the street declare that he, too, could have been a king if he had been born in the purple; for that potentiality does not belong to him as he is, but only as he might have been, if underscore per impossibile underscore he had not been himself.

column2: There is a strange metaphysical illusion in imagining that a man might change his parents, his body, his early environment, and yet retain his personality.
column3: There is a strange metaphysical illusion in imagining that a man might change his parents, his body, his early environment, and yet retain his personality.

column2: In its higher faculties his personality is produced by his special relations.
column3: In its higher faculties his personality is produced by his special relations.

column2: If Shakespeare had been born in Italy he might, if you will, have been a great poet, but Shakespeare he could never have been.
column3: If Shakespeare had been born in Italy he might, if you will, have been a great poet, but Shakespeare he could never have been.

column2: Nor can it be called an injustice to all of us who are not Englishmen of Queen Elizabeth's time that Shakespeare had that advantage and was thereby enabled to exist.
column3: Nor can it be called an injustice to all of us who are not Englishmen of Queen Elizabeth's time that Shakespeare had that advantage and was thereby enabled to exist.

column2: The sense of injustice at unequal opportunities arises only when the two environments compared are really somewhat analogous, so that the illusion of a change of roles without a change of characters may retain some colour.
column3: The sense of injustice at unequal opportunities arises only when the two environments compared are really somewhat analogous, so that the illusion of a change of roles without a change of characters may retain some colour.

column2: It was a just insight, for instance, in the Christian fable to make the first rebel against God the chief among the angels, the spirit occupying the position nearest to that which he tried to usurp. Lucifer's fallacy consisted in thinking natural inequality artificial. His perversity lay in rebelling against himself and rejecting the happiness proper to his nature.
column3: It was a just insight, for instance, in the Christian fable to make the first rebel against God the chief among the angels, the spirit occupying the position nearest to that which he tried to usurp. Lucifer's fallacy consisted in thinking natural inequality artificial. His perversity lay in rebelling against himself and rejecting the happiness proper to his nature.

column2: This was the maddest possible way of rebelling against his true creator; for it is our particular finitude that creates us and makes us be.
column3: This was the maddest possible way of rebelling against his true creator; for it is our particular finitude that creates us and makes us be.

column2: No one, except in wilful fancy, would envy the peculiar advantages of a whale or an ant, of an Inca or a Grand Lama.
column3: No one, except in wilful fancy, would envy the peculiar advantages of a whale or an ant, of an Inca or a Grand Lama.

column2: An exchange of places with such remote beings would too evidently leave each creature the very same that it was before; for after a nominal exchange of places each office would remain filled and no trace of a change would be perceptible.
column3: An exchange of places with such remote beings would too evidently leave each creature the very same that it was before; for after a nominal exchange of places each office would remain filled and no trace of a change would be perceptible.

column2: But the penny that one man finds and another misses would not, had fortune been reversed, have transmuted each man into the other.
column3: But the penny that one man finds and another misses would not, had fortune been reversed, have transmuted each man into the other.

column2: So adventitious a circumstance seems easily transferable without undermining that personal distinction which it had come to embitter.
column3: So adventitious a circumstance seems easily transferable without undermining that personal distinction which it had come to embitter.

column2: Yet the incipient fallacy lurking even in such suppositions becomes obvious when we inquire whether so blind an accident, for instance, as sex is also adventitious and ideally transferable and whether Jack and Jill, remaining themselves, could have exchanged genders.
column3: Yet the incipient fallacy lurking even in such suppositions becomes obvious when we inquire whether so blind an accident, for instance, as sex is also adventitious and ideally transferable and whether Jack and Jill, remaining themselves, could have exchanged genders.

column2: What extends these invidious comparisons beyond all tolerable bounds is the generic and vague nature proper to language and its terms.
column3: What extends these invidious comparisons beyond all tolerable bounds is the generic and vague nature proper to language and its terms.

column2: The first personal pronoun "I" is a concept so thoroughly universal that it can accompany any experience whatever, yet it is used to designate an individual who is really definable not by the formal selfhood which he shares with every other thinker, but by the special events that make up his life.
column3: The first personal pronoun "I" is a concept so thoroughly universal that it can accompany any experience whatever, yet it is used to designate an individual who is really definable not by the formal selfhood which he shares with every other thinker, but by the special events that make up his life.

column2: Each man's memory embraces a certain field, and if the landscape open to his vision is sad and hateful he naturally wishes it to shift and become like that paradise in which, as he fancies, other men dwell.
column3: Each man's memory embraces a certain field, and if the landscape open to his vision is sad and hateful he naturally wishes it to shift and become like that paradise in which, as he fancies, other men dwell.

column2: A legitimate rebellion against evil in his own experience becomes an unthinkable supposition about what his experience might have been had _he_ enjoyed those other men's opportunities or even (so far can unreason wander) had _he_ possessed their character.
column3: A legitimate rebellion against evil in his own experience becomes an unthinkable supposition about what his experience might have been had underscore he underscore enjoyed those other men's opportunities or even (so far can unreason wander) had underscore he underscore possessed their character.

column2: The wholly different creature, a replica of that envied ideal, which would have existed in that case would still have called itself "I"; and so, the dreamer imagines, that creature would have been himself in a different situation.
column3: The wholly different creature, a replica of that envied ideal, which would have existed in that case would still have called itself "I"; and so, the dreamer imagines, that creature would have been himself in a different situation.

column2: If a new birth could still be called by a man's own name, the reason would be that the concrete faculties now present in him are the basis for the ideal he throws out, and if these particular faculties came to fruition in a new being, he would call that being himself, inasmuch as it realised his ideal.
column3: If a new birth could still be called by a man's own name, the reason would be that the concrete faculties now present in him are the basis for the ideal he throws out, and if these particular faculties came to fruition in a new being, he would call that being himself, inasmuch as it realised his ideal.

column2: The poorer the reality, therefore, the meaner and vaguer the ideal it is able to project.
column3: The poorer the reality, therefore, the meaner and vaguer the ideal it is able to project.

column2: Man is so tied to his personal endowment (essential to him though an accident in the world) that even his uttermost ideal, into which he would fly out of himself and his finitude, can be nothing but the fulfilment of his own initial idiosyncrasies.
column3: Man is so tied to his personal endowment (essential to him though an accident in the world) that even his uttermost ideal, into which he would fly out of himself and his finitude, can be nothing but the fulfilment of his own initial idiosyncrasies.

column2: Whatever other wills and other glories may exist in heaven lie not within his universe of aspiration.
column3: Whatever other wills and other glories may exist in heaven lie not within his universe of aspiration.

column2: Even his most perversely metaphysical envy can begrudge to others only what he instinctively craves for himself.
column3: Even his most perversely metaphysical envy can begrudge to others only what he instinctively craves for himself.

column2: [Sidenote: Inequality is not a grievance; suffering is.]
column3: [Sidenote: Inequality is not a grievance; suffering is.]

column2: It is not mere inequality, therefore, that can be a reproach to the aristocratic or theistic ideal.
column3: It is not mere inequality, therefore, that can be a reproach to the aristocratic or theistic ideal.

column2: Could each person fulfil his own nature the most striking differences in endowment and fortune would trouble nobody's dreams.
column3: Could each person fulfil his own nature the most striking differences in endowment and fortune would trouble nobody's dreams.

column2: The true reproach to which aristocracy and theism are open is the thwarting of those unequal natures and the consequent suffering imposed on them all.
column3: The true reproach to which aristocracy and theism are open is the thwarting of those unequal natures and the consequent suffering imposed on them all.

column2: Injustice in this world is not something comparative; the wrong is deep, clear, and absolute in each private fate.
column3: Injustice in this world is not something comparative; the wrong is deep, clear, and absolute in each private fate.

column2: A bruised child wailing in the street, his small world for the moment utterly black and cruel before him, does not fetch his unhappiness from sophisticated comparisons or irrational envy; nor can any compensations and celestial harmonies supervening later ever expunge or justify that moment's bitterness.
column3: A bruised child wailing in the street, his small world for the moment utterly black and cruel before him, does not fetch his unhappiness from sophisticated comparisons or irrational envy; nor can any compensations and celestial harmonies supervening later ever expunge or justify that moment's bitterness.

column2: The pain may be whistled away and forgotten; the mind may be rendered by it only a little harder, a little coarser, a little more secretive and sullen and familiar with unrightable wrong.
column3: The pain may be whistled away and forgotten; the mind may be rendered by it only a little harder, a little coarser, a little more secretive and sullen and familiar with unrightable wrong.

column2: But ignoring that pain will not prevent its having existed; it must remain for ever to trouble God's omniscience and be a part of that hell which the creation too truly involves.
column3: But ignoring that pain will not prevent its having existed; it must remain for ever to trouble God's omniscience and be a part of that hell which the creation too truly involves.

column2: [Sidenote: Mutilation by crowding.]
column3: [Sidenote: Mutilation by crowding.]

column2: The same curse of suffering vitiates Agrippa's ingenious parable and the joyful humility of Dante's celestial friends, and renders both equally irrelevant to human conditions.
column3: The same curse of suffering vitiates Agrippa's ingenious parable and the joyful humility of Dante's celestial friends, and renders both equally irrelevant to human conditions.

column2: Nature may arrange her hierarchies as she chooses and make her creatures instrumental to one another's life. That interrelation is no injury to any part and an added beauty in the whole.
column3: Nature may arrange her hierarchies as she chooses and make her creatures instrumental to one another's life. That interrelation is no injury to any part and an added beauty in the whole.

column2: It would have been a truly admirable arrangement to have enabled every living being, in attaining its own end, to make the attainments of the others' ends possible to them also.
column3: It would have been a truly admirable arrangement to have enabled every living being, in attaining its own end, to make the attainments of the others' ends possible to them also.

column2: An approach to such an equilibrium has actually been reached in some respects by the rough sifting of miscellaneous organisms until those that were compatible alone remained.
column3: An approach to such an equilibrium has actually been reached in some respects by the rough sifting of miscellaneous organisms until those that were compatible alone remained.

column2: But nature, in her haste to be fertile, wants to produce everything at once, and her distracted industry has brought about terrible confusion and waste and terrible injustice.
column3: But nature, in her haste to be fertile, wants to produce everything at once, and her distracted industry has brought about terrible confusion and waste and terrible injustice.

column2: She has been led to punish her ministers for the services they render and her favourites for the honours they receive.
column3: She has been led to punish her ministers for the services they render and her favourites for the honours they receive.

column2: She has imposed suffering on her creatures together with life; she has defeated her own objects and vitiated her bounty by letting every good do harm and bring evil in its train to some unsuspecting creature.
column3: She has imposed suffering on her creatures together with life; she has defeated her own objects and vitiated her bounty by letting every good do harm and bring evil in its train to some unsuspecting creature.
